In this Note, we'll take a quick look at all 7 Habits‚Äîfrom being proactive (huge!) to beginning with the end in mind, putting first things first, thinking win/win, seeking first to understand, synergizing and sharpening the saw. Lots of goodness here to help us develop our character to create our ideal lives as we most fully give ourselves to the world.

title: Meditations
author: Marcus Aurelius
desc: Marcus Aurelius was the Emperor-Philosopher of the Roman Empire and one of the most enlightened leaders ever. Meditations is a collection of journal entries he wrote to himself and in this Note, we'll explore some Big Ideas of his Stoic philosophy‚Äîfrom the importance of never confusing ourselves with visions of a lifetime all at once, to not worrying about what others think of us and living a life of purpose and service.

title: Tiny Habits
subtitle: The Small Changes That Change Everything
author: B. J. Fogg
desc: BJ Fogg founded the Behavior Design Lab at Stanford University. He is one of the world‚Äôs leading authorities on the science of behavior change. In this book, he introduces us to the core elements of his Fogg Behavior Model as we learn that habit change doesn‚Äôt need to be as hard as we make it. As BJ tells us: ‚ÄúWe are not the problem. Our approach to change is. It‚Äôs a design flaw‚Äînot a personal flaw.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include the three elements that drive behavior (B = MAP!), the ABCs of Tiny Habits (Anchor + (Tiny) Behavior + Celebration!), the power of anchor prompts (After I (ANCHOR), I will (NEW HABIT), and the power of celebration (get your Shine on!).

title: Man's Search For Meaning
subtitle: An Introduction to Logotherapy
author: Viktor Frankl
desc: Viktor Frankl survived the horrors of the holocaust and describes his Logotherapy in this classic book. In the Note, we'll explore the fact that our attitudes determine our happiness and that *no one* can ever take away the freedom for us to choose our response to any given situation. We'll also look at the importance of having a mission in life and that as we serve something bigger than ourselves, our happiness and success will follow.

title: The Daily Stoic
subtitle: 366 Meditations on Wisdom, Perseverance, and the Art of Living
author: Ryan Holiday, Stephen Hanselman
desc: This book combines two of my favorite things: Stoicism + Ryan Holiday‚Äôs wisdom. Stoicism was one of the most influential philosophy of the Roman world and has continued to influence many of history‚Äôs greatest minds. As Ryan says: It‚Äôs time to bring it back as a powerful tool ‚Äúin the pursuit of self-mastery, perseverance, and wisdom.‚Äù This is one of the my favorite books ever. Big Ideas we explore: the #1 thing to know about Stoicism, how to create tranquility, a good answer to ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the latest and greatest?!,‚Äù the 2 essential tasks in life and the art of acquiescence (aka amor fati).

title: Rethinking Positive Thinking
subtitle: Inside the New Science of Motivation
author: Gabriele Oettingen
desc: Gabriel Oettingen is one of the world‚Äôs leading researchers in ‚ÄúThe New Science of Motivation.‚Äù The basic idea of the book is captured in a clever image on the cover: Rose colored glasses with one lens cracked. Oettingen walks us thru the compelling research that demonstrates the power of seeing both the positive AND the challenges. When we contrast our wishes with the obstacles to their attainment we, almost magically, catalyze an extraordinarily higher level of performance.

title: Mindset
subtitle: The New Psychology of Success
author: Carol Dweck
desc: Carol Dweck, Ph.D is a Stanford Professor and one of the world‚Äôs leading authorities on the science of motivation. She tells us that our ‚Äúmindset‚Äù‚Äîhow we see the world‚Äîdetermines a *huge* part of our overall happiness and well-being and achievement. In this Note, we‚Äôll explore the difference between a ‚Äúfixed mindset‚Äù and a ‚Äúgrowth mindset‚Äù and some Big Ideas on why we want to learn how to live from a growth mindset. And, of course, how to do it!

title: Principles
subtitle: Life and Work
author: Ray Dalio
desc: Ray Dalio is one of the most successful people alive. In fact, Time magazine says that he‚Äôs one of the 100 most influential people on the planet while Fortune magazine tells us his company (Bridgewater Associates) is the 5th most impactful private company in the U.S. and Forbes tells us that he‚Äôs one of the 100 wealthiest people on the planet. All of which makes Dalio, to use his words, ‚Äúbelievable‚Äù when it comes to discussing how to get what we want in life and work. Enter: Principles. Big Ideas we explore: how to evolve, what‚Äôs most important, meet the shapers, Principles #1 (Embrace reality and deal with it) + #2 (5-Step process to getting what you want in life), and the two AI‚Äôs: Artificial Intelligence + Ancient Intelligence.

title: The ONE Thing
subtitle: The Surprisingly Simple Truth Behind Extraordinary Results
author: Gary Keller, Jay Papasan
desc: The ONE Thing. What's yours? Gary Keller (his Keller-Williams real estate is THE largest real estate company in the world--I bet that was a ONE Thing goal at some point!) shares his wisdom in this BRILLIANT book. We'll have fun exploring a few of my favorite Big Ideas: dominoes + extreme Pareto and other goodness.

title: The 5 Second Rule
subtitle: Transform Your Life, Work, and Confidence with Everyday Courage
author: Mel Robbins
desc: Mel Robbins is funny, witty and wise. Her TEDx Talk (called How to stop screwing yourself over) is one of the most popular of all time, with more than 18 million views. This book is also super popular‚Äîwith over 1,000 Amazon reviews. It‚Äôs pretty awesome. Actually, the book is REALLY (!) good. In fact, Mel Robbins‚Äô 5 Second Rule might just be one of THE most elegantly efficient Tools we can use to close the gap between who we‚Äôre CAPABLE of being and who we‚Äôre ACTUALLY being. (Seriously.) Big Ideas we explore include The 5 Second Rule (and how/when to rock it), how to win the game of life (hint: start, stay in, for the long game!), excitement + anxiety (and how they feel the same in the body), managing distractions (today a good day?), and changing your life with one moment of everyday courage.

title: Flourish
subtitle: A Visionary New Understanding of Happiness and Well-being
author: Martin Seligman
desc: Martin Seligman is one of the founding fathers of the Positive Psychology movement and this is the third Note we‚Äôve done on one of his books. (Check out the Notes on his other classics: Learned Optimism and Authentic Happiness for more science of happiness goodness.) In this Note, we‚Äôll explore his shift from Authentic Happiness Theory to Well-Being Theory as we wrap our brains around PERMA, his model of well-being that consists of Positive emotions + Engagement + Relationships + Meaning + Achievement. Good times.

title: The Obstacle Is the Way
subtitle: The Timeless Art of Turning Trials into Triumph
author: Ryan Holiday
desc: Ryan Holiday is brilliant. So is this book. The ancient Stoics taught us how to not only accept challenges but to thrive on them. Ryan brings their wisdom to life with compelling stories of great peeps who have rocked it in the face of adversity. In the Note we'll take a quick look at the three keys to making obstacles work for us: Perception + Action + Will.

title: The Compound Effect
subtitle: Jumpstart Your Income, Your Life, Your Success
author: Darren Hardy
desc: Darren Hardy is the Publisher of SUCCESS magazine and knows a thing or 1,000 about success. It's all boiled down into this little manifesto on The Compound Effect. The equation? Small, Smart Choices + Consistency + Time = RADICAL DIFFERENCE. In the Note, we'll check out the power of compounding and how to welcome Mr. Mo to the party and create your greatest life.

title: Why We Sleep
subtitle: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
author: Matthew Walker PhD
desc: Matthew Walker is one of the world‚Äôs leading neuroscientists and sleep experts. He‚Äôs a professor at UC Berkeley (and former professor at Harvard) who has spent decades studying why we sleep and how to, as per the sub-title of this book, unlock the power of sleep and dreams. As you know if you‚Äôve been following along, I‚Äôm a HUGE advocate of Optimizing our sleep as a fundamental practice in Optimizing our lives. This book has made me EVEN MORE bullish about the power of sleep. The consequences of chronically depriving ourselves of the sleep we need? Well, they‚Äôre astonishingly devastating‚Äîdramatically increasing the odds of having everything from mood disorders to cancer (and everything else we don‚Äôt want). Big Ideas we explore include the fact that you're more likely to get struck by lightning than have the gene that let's you get by on less than the recommended sleep, the universality of sleep (even worms sleep!!), resetting baselines, the iPad effect (did you know how much using one before sleep messes w/your melatonin?), and some tips to Optimize your sleep TONIGHT!!!

title: With Winning in Mind
subtitle: The Mental Management System
author: Lanny Bassham
desc: This is a SHOCKINGLY good book. Want to get your mind right? Lanny Bassham, an Olympic gold medalist, has been teaching the art of mental training/peak performance for decades and this book tells us just how to rock it. In the Note, we'll look at the importance of making the process primary and other fundamentals of mental mastery.

title: Everything Is Figureoutable
author: Marie Forleo
desc: My wife Alexandra has been a huge fan of Marie‚Äôs for a long time. I knew she was awesome. But... As I told Alexandra: ‚ÄúI had no idea Marie was THAT awesome!!!‚Äù My excuse: I‚Äôve been in hermit-mode and have done nothing but read books for 5 years (no blogs/videos/etc.) so I wasn‚Äôt able to get the full sense of Marie‚Äôs heroically brilliant and grounded and HILARIOUS power until this book came out. I‚Äôve read and created PhilosophersNotes on well over 500 books. This is one of my ABSOLUTE (!) favorites of all time. I HIGHLY (!!!) recommend it. It‚Äôs in the same league as some of my other favorites like Deep Work Atomic Habits and The 5 Second Rule. (In fact, on my chalkboard right now, I actually have ‚ÄúEVERYTHING IS FIGUREOUTABLE‚Äù right above ‚Äú5-4-3-2-1-GO!‚Äù ‚Üê Winning combo!) The book is PACKED (!) with Big Ideas and I‚Äôm excited to share a few of my favorites so let‚Äôs jump straight in!

title: Happy Together
subtitle: Using the Science of Positive Psychology to Build Love That Lasts
author: Suzann Pileggi Pawelski, MAPP, James O. Pawelski Ph.D.
desc: Suzie and James Pawelski are two of the world's leading positive psychology experts. James cofounded the Master of Applied Positive Psychology program at the University of Pennsylvania with Martin Seligman while Suzie is a graduate of the program and a leading freelance writer and consultant. Together they've written an incredible book on "Using the Science of Positive Psychology to Build Love That Lasts." I‚Äôve been waiting for a very long time for the book that would make me say: ‚ÄúREAD THIS BOOK if you want to figure out how to integrate Ancient Wisdom + Modern Science + Practical Tools to Optimize your relationship.‚Äù And, well, THIS book is it. I HIGHLY recommend it. In fact, it's not only my #1 Love book recommendation, it's also cracked the Top 10 all-time greatest list. Big Ideas we explore include The Relationship Gym (hit it!), Aristotelian Lovers (the REAL Soul Mates), SNAP (James geniuses x2), Know Thy... (self and thy partner!), and Love Is an Action Verb (let's commit to flourishing together TODAY!).

title: Coming Alive
subtitle: 4 Tools to Defeat Your Inner Enemy, Ignite Creative Expression & Unleash Your Soul‚Äôs Potential
author: Phil Stutz, Barry Michels

Big Ideas we explore include how to connect to our Life Force, defeat Part X (their name for that part of each of us that gets in the way), build our confidence and learn to see problems as gifts as we live a GREAT life.

title: Unbeatable Mind
subtitle: Forge Resiliency and Mental Toughness to Succeed at an Elite Level
author: Mark Divine
desc: I'm convinced Mark Divine is a superhero. Seriously. And in Unbeatable Mind, the former Navy SEAL gives us the handbook on mental toughness. In the Note, we'll look at the keys to cultivating our confidence, the importance of cultivating our concentration, learning how to control our breathing and other goodness that will make you unbeatable.

title: Presence
subtitle: Bringing Your Boldest Self to Your Biggest Challenges
author: Amy Cuddy
desc: Amy Cuddy is awesome. Her TED talk is the 2nd most popular ever. This book is just as good. Learn the science of cultivating your personal power to bring your boldest self to your biggest challenges. Big Ideas we explore: self-affirmation theory, priming + nudges, the magic of expanding your body to increase your power, iHunch (how‚Äôs yours?), and the boldest you.

title: The Bhagavad Gita
subtitle: A Classic of Indian Spirituality
author: Krishna, Eknath Easwaran
desc: The classic text of Hinduism is *packed* with wisdom. In the Note, we take a super quick look at the context for the book and then jump into some powerful wisdom‚Äîincluding the importance of meditation, the fact that making mistakes is an inherent part of our growth process and the uber-importance of letting go of our attachment to results.

title: The 80/20 Principle
subtitle: The Secret to Success by Achieving More With Less
author: Richard Koch
desc: Did you know 20% of beer drinkers drink 80% of the beer? And that 20% of streets account for 80% of the traffic? And that most peeps wear 20% of their clothes 80% of the time? In this Note, we‚Äôll explore the 80/20 principle and how we can apply its power to every aspect of our lives to "achieve more with less."

title: Self-theories
subtitle: Their Role in Motivation, Personality, and Development (Essays in Social Psychology)
author: Carol Dweck
desc: Carol Dweck is one of the world‚Äôs leading researchers on the science of motivation. This book is a collection of brief essays on various aspects of ‚Äúself-theories.‚Äù It‚Äôs essentially a bridge between her extensive academic research studies and her popular book Mindset. It‚Äôs amazing. Big Ideas we explore include the two frameworks (entity vs. incremental) and their two goals (performance vs. learning), attributional retraining (aka learning the best way to respond to failure!), and moving from contingent self-worth to wholehearted self-esteem.

title: The How of Happiness
subtitle: A Scientific Approach to Getting the Life You Want
author: Sonja Lyubomirsky
desc: People often ask me what *one* book I would recommend they read. I never had an answer I felt good about until I read this book. It's amazing. The most comprehensive and readable look at what we *scientifically know* works to boost our happiness‚Äîfrom gratitude and exercise to optimism and kindness. (btw: The other #1 book I'd recommend? The PhilosophersNotes workbook. How can you beat 1,000 Big Ideas from 100 great books packed into 600 pages? ;)

title: So Good They Can't Ignore You
subtitle: Why Skills Trump Passion in the Quest for Work You Love
author: Cal Newport
desc: Cal Newport decodes the pattern of finding work that inspires us and tells us, as per the sub-title, ‚ÄúWhy Skills Trump Passion in the Quest for Work You Love.‚Äù The title of the book comes from comedian Steve Martin‚Äôs advice to aspiring entertainers to ‚ÄúBe so good they can‚Äôt ignore you.‚Äù

title: Letters from a Stoic
author: Seneca
desc: Seneca. He was born around the same time as Jesus and was one of the leading figures in his Roman Empire. He was also one of history's leading Stoic philosophers (along with Marcus Aurelius and Epictetus who we also profile) and has some powerful wisdom to share. In this Note, we'll explore the purpose of philosophy, the importance of focusing our attention and the mojo that comes from facing our fears.

title: Peak
subtitle: Secrets from the New Science of Expertise
author: Anders Ericsson, Robert Pool
desc: Anders Ericsson is the world‚Äôs leading scientist studying expert performance‚Äîlooking at how, precisely, the people who are the best in the world at what they do became the best. title: Motivation and Personality
author: Abraham Maslow
desc: Abraham Maslow tells us, "What one can be, one must be!" (OMG I love that.) In this Note, we'll explore some of the Big Ideas on how we can be all that we're destined to be and look at some of the characteristics of those self-actualizing human beings who're rockin' it.

title: Flow
subtitle: The Psychology of Optimal Experience
author: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
desc: Flow. It's all about the science of optimal human experience. In this Note, we'll explore what the flow state is (hint: get fully engaged in an activity that matches your skills with your challenge) and we‚Äôll look at some other Big Ideas on controlling the contents of our consciousness to get out of anxiety and boredom as we create more flow experiences in our lives. (Plus, you'll even learn how to pronounce "Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi.")

title: Stillness Is the Key
author: Ryan Holiday

Screenwriter and director Brian Koppelman (Rounders, Ocean‚Äôs Thirteen and Billions) puts it this way: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have many rules in life, but one I never break is: If Ryan Holiday writes a book, I read it as soon as I can get my hands on it.‚Äù (btw: Cal Newport‚Äôs the first testimonial. He says: ‚ÄúSome authors give advice. Ryan Holiday distills wisdom. This book is a must read.‚Äù) Penguin Random House sent me an advance copy of this book. As I knew it would be: It‚Äôs fantastic. Of course, the book‚Äôs packed with Big Ideas and I‚Äôm excited to share some of my favorites so let‚Äôs jump straight in!

title: The 4 Disciplines of Execution
subtitle: Achieving Your Wildly Important Goals
author: Chris McChesney, Sean Covey, Jim Huling
desc: I planned to read this book since Cal Newport referenced it in Deep Work. I finally did so in preparation to teach Productivity 101. It‚Äôs fantastic. If you‚Äôre a business leader or entrepreneur I think you‚Äôll particularly enjoy it. Big Ideas we cover include the 4DX, the whirlwind, your Wildly Important Goals, Lag vs. Lead measures, the power of keeping score, and avoiding the blackhole of the magnificently trivial.

title: How to Think Like Leonardo da Vinci
subtitle: Seven Steps to Genius Every Day
author: Michael Gelb

title: The Nicomachean Ethics

Some of my favorites we cover include the ultimate end: eudaimonic happiness (vs. "happiness" as most of us think about it!), how to achieve that eudaimonia (hint: "virtuous activity of the soul" aka aret√©), how to win the Olympic Games (hint: you can't just show up; you need to ACT!), the doctrine of the mean (and the vice of deficiency + excess) and the virtue of magnanimity: meet YOUR great soul.

title: Extreme Ownership
subtitle: How U.S. Navy SEALs Lead and Win
author: Jocko Willink, Leif Babin

Big Ideas we explore include a definition of Extreme Ownership, the fact that there are no bad teams, only bad leaders, how to prioritize and execute and remembering that discipline = freedom.

title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
author: Dale Carnegie
desc: Dale Carnegie wrote this book in 1937. The publisher originally only printed 5,000 copies. It was an immediate best seller and went on to sell over 30 million copies. I‚Äôve always had a very strong allergy to the idea of ‚Äúnetworking‚Äù and trying to ‚Äúwin friends‚Äù and/or ‚Äúinfluence people‚Äù so this one never quite resonated but I loved it. It‚Äôs packed with Big Ideas on how to Optimize our relationships and, perhaps in the process, win some more friends and influence some people as better humans and leaders. We explore: The #1 indispensable quality you need for Optimizing, Principle #1 of How to Win Friends (Never criticize!!), how to make a great first impression, the Golden Rule (you living it), what to do when you make a mistake, and what to think when you meet people today!

title: On the Shortness of Life

author: Seneca
desc: Seneca was an old-school Roman statesman and one of history‚Äôs leading Stoic philosophers. In this book he tells us that life is only short if you don‚Äôt know how to use it and also gives us some tips on how to deal with challenging times and cultivate tranquility. Big Ideas we explore include making T.O.D.A.Y. the day, how to deal with being exiled (never know when it could happen ;), and why flexibility is the virtuous road to tranquility (and how to avoid the detours).

title: Happier
subtitle: Learn the Secrets to Daily Joy and Lasting Fulfillment
author: Tal Ben-Shahar
desc: Tal Ben-Shahar is one of my favorite teachers. We'll explore how important it is to have goals AND be in the moment (and the perils of *just* being in the moment) along with mucho m√°s goodness.

title: The Second Mountain
subtitle: The Quest for a Moral Life
author: David Brooks
desc: David Brooks is one of the nations‚Äô leading writers and commentators. He is an op-ed columnist for the New York Times and appears regularly on PBS NewsHour and Meet the Press. That‚Äôs what society tells us we should pursue: all the normal trappings of success. The second mountain? That‚Äôs where the magic (and joy!) exists: where we move beyond ourselves and COMMIT (important word for this book!) to giving ourselves most fully to something bigger than ourselves. David identifies four potential commitments: to our families, to our vocations, to our faith/philosophy of life and to our communities. Ultimately, the book is intended to be a guide to the ULTIMATE quest in life: ‚ÄúThe Quest for a Moral Life.‚Äù

title: The Power of Full Engagement
subtitle: Managing Energy, Not Time, Is the Key to High Performance and Personal Renewal
author: James E. Loehr, Tony Schwartz
desc: Loehr and Schwartz tell us we've gotta manage ENERGY not time if we wanna really optimize our lives. Their book is pure goodness. And some other really Big Ideas on getting our Full Engagement on.

title: The Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

We'll have fun tapping into a lot more of his vast mojo in the Note.

title: The Dhammapada

author: Eknath Easwaran
desc: A core text of Buddhism, The Dhammapada literally means something along the lines of "the path of truth and righteousness" and is packed with wisdom. title: Digital Minimalism
subtitle: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Cal Newport
desc: Cal Newport is one of my favorite thinkers. He got his Ph.D. in Computer Science from MIT and is now a Professor at Georgetown. He‚Äôs also a bestselling author of a number of books. Big Ideas we explore include the fact that your soul is engaged in a lopsided arms race, a definition + overview of digital minimalism, the importance of spending time alone (and the consequences of *not* spending adequate time alone), reclaiming leisure (get active!) and joining the Attention Resistance. Here's to Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World!

Big Ideas we explore include: Mental Contrasting (and why it beats creative visualization), goal setting (3 scientific keys) and how to add a month of productivity to your year.

title: The Willpower Instinct

author: Kelly McGonigal
desc: Willpower. It‚Äôs huge. The Willpower Instinct by award-winning Stanford Professor Kelly McGonigal, Ph.D., is a GREAT book based on ‚ÄúThe Science of Willpower‚Äù class Kelly teaches through Stanford University‚Äôs Continuing Studies program. It‚Äôs *packed* with super practical Big Ideas on the newest scientific insights about self-control to explain how we can ‚Äúbreak old habits and create healthy habits, conquer procrastination, find our focus, and manage stress.‚Äù In this Note, we‚Äôll check out the #1 way to build willpower (it‚Äôs not what you‚Äôd guess), how to give ourselves willpower boosts throughout the day and other stress-relief strategies that rock.

title: Gratitude Works!
subtitle: A 21-Day Program for Creating Emotional Prosperity
author: Robert A. Emmons
desc: I‚Äôm grateful for Robert Emmons. He‚Äôs dedicated the last three decades of his life to understanding the science of how to boost our well-being. In the process, he‚Äôs conducted ground-breaking research on the power of gratitude. In fact, he‚Äôs basically THE researcher we have to thank for understanding *just* how powerful gratitude journaling is. (He's also served as editor-in-chief of The Journal of Positive Psychology.) Big Ideas we explore include: How to give yourself a 25% (!!!) boost in happiness, the top gratitude practices, the #1 obstacle to gratitude (and its remedy), and using challenges for grateful fuel!

title: 12 Rules for Life
subtitle: An Antidote to Chaos
author: Jordan B. Peterson
desc: Jordan Peterson is one of the world's leading intellectuals. He's a Canadian clinical psychologist and professor at the University of Toronto. (Before that, he taught at Harvard.) Peterson‚Äôs integration of everything from evolutionary psychology, politics, religion and morality is astounding. After taking a super-quick look at all 12 Rules, Big Ideas we cover include the importance of mastering the flow or Order + Chaos (and why RULES are so important), Rule #1 (stand up straight, shoulders back! Remember lobsters...), Rule #2 (Treat yourself better! Remember pets...), Rule #6: Clean up your life (remember to start stopping...), and the fact that your Being is in your Becoming (which is connected to Rule #4...).

title: Self-Reliance
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
desc: Ralph Waldo Emerson. He‚Äôs the great-great-grandfather in my spiritual family tree. title: The War of Art

title: Willpower
subtitle: Rediscovering the Greatest Human Strength
author: Roy Baumeister, John Tierney

author: Joseph Campbell

author: Steven Pressfield

author: Rumi

We have some great Notes on Movement (Spark, Spartan Up and No Sweat among my favorites), but Kelly‚Äôs book will be our new go-to for the science of WHY exercise/movement is so essential to our well-being. Reading about the SCIENCE behind stories of transformation (and how, as per the sub-title of her book: ‚ÄúExercise Helps Us Find Happiness, Hope, Connection, and Courage‚Äù) also made me that much more clear on the power of what we‚Äôre doing with all of our work and the importance of focusing so much on Energy (especially with our Mastery and Coach programs). Big Ideas we explore include: Hope Molecules (and how to create them), persistence highs (and how to create them), collective effervescence (and why it's so awesome), how we endure (hint: TOGETHER!), and OMMS!!! (Obstacles (literally!) Make Me Stronger!).

title: What Doesn't Kill Us
subtitle: The New Psychology of Posttraumatic Growth
author: Stephen Joseph Ph.D.
desc: Stephen Joseph is one of the world‚Äôs leading researchers on the science of posttraumatic growth. He is also a professor and therapist. He started his career studying posttraumatic stress. In the process, he saw that many people experienced significant growth as a result of the stress they endured--at which point, he started developing his ideas on posttraumatic growth. Fast-forward a few decades and here we are. the title is a play on Nietzsche‚Äôs famous dictum: ‚ÄúWhat doesn‚Äôt kill me makes me stronger.‚Äù While the sub-title perfectly captures the focus of the book: ‚ÄúThe New Psychology of Posttraumatic Growth.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include: Eudaimonic Treadmills (note: there aren't any!), posttraumatic growth (and how to use stress as the engine for growth), the shattered vase (taking the pieces and making an antifragile mosaic), harvesting hope (the 1 + 2 + 3s for trauma survivors).

title: Peak
subtitle: Secrets from the New Science of Expertise
author: Anders Ericsson, Robert Pool
desc: Anders Ericsson is the world‚Äôs leading scientist studying expert performance‚Äîlooking at how, precisely, the people who are the best in the world at what they do became the best. In this Note, we take a quick look at The Gift that we all have that‚Äôs the key to our potential greatness, HOW to go about tapping into the benefits of that gift via a certain type of practice (forget naive practice and go for purposeful + deliberate!), the fact that there is no such thing as a ‚Äú10,000 Hour Rule,‚Äù and why we should be called Homo Exercens rather than Homo Sapiens. :)

title: Presence
subtitle: Bringing Your Boldest Self to Your Biggest Challenges
author: Amy Cuddy
desc: Amy Cuddy is awesome. Her TED talk is the 2nd most popular ever. This book is just as good. Learn the science of cultivating your personal power to bring your boldest self to your biggest challenges. Big Ideas we explore: self-affirmation theory, priming + nudges, the magic of expanding your body to increase your power, iHunch (how‚Äôs yours?), and the boldest you.

title: Happier
subtitle: Learn the Secrets to Daily Joy and Lasting Fulfillment
author: Tal Ben-Shahar
desc: Tal Ben-Shahar is one of my favorite teachers. He taught one of the most popular classes in Harvard's history and this book captures the essence of his class on Positive Psychology‚Äîsharing the best of what we scientifically know about how to create happier, more fulfilled lives. We'll explore how important it is to have goals AND be in the moment (and the perils of *just* being in the moment) along with mucho m√°s goodness.

title: Gratitude Works!
subtitle: A 21-Day Program for Creating Emotional Prosperity
author: Robert A. Emmons
desc: I‚Äôm grateful for Robert Emmons. He‚Äôs dedicated the last three decades of his life to understanding the science of how to boost our well-being. In the process, he‚Äôs conducted ground-breaking research on the power of gratitude. In fact, he‚Äôs basically THE researcher we have to thank for understanding *just* how powerful gratitude journaling is. (He's also served as editor-in-chief of The Journal of Positive Psychology.) I consider myself a reasonably grateful guy but this book has opened my eyes to JUST how powerful gratitude is. And, to just how important it is to DELIBERATELY PRACTICE it. Big Ideas we explore include: How to give yourself a 25% (!!!) boost in happiness, the top gratitude practices, the #1 obstacle to gratitude (and its remedy), and using challenges for grateful fuel!

title: Future Visions
subtitle: The Unpublished Papers of Abraham Maslow
author: Dr. Edward Hoffman
desc: As you know if you‚Äôve been following along, I love Abraham Maslow and feel a deep kinship to him and his work. We have featured two of the books he published during his lifetime: Toward a Psychology of Being and Motivation and Personality. Although this book has only ONE review on Amazon and I could only buy a used copy of it, I knew I‚Äôd love it. And, although I had already been deeply influenced by Maslow and his thinking, there was something about reading his unpublished essays and journal thoughts that made me feel that much more connected to this great man. Big Ideas we explore include Maslow‚Äôs thoughts on the ‚Äúeupsychian ideal‚Äù (aka: the ‚Äúeudaemonic ideal‚Äù!), the psychology of happiness (eudaimonology!!), Stoic philosophy (Maslow was a fan), vicious cultural influences (Maslow was NOT a fan!), and the Jonah Complex (ANSWER YOUR HEROIC CALL, already!!).

title: The Awakened Brain
subtitle: The New Science of Spirituality and Our Quest for an Inspired Life
author: Lisa Miller, Ph.D.
desc: Did you know that there‚Äôs a ‚ÄúScience of Spirituality‚Äù? Yep. There is. It‚Äôs fascinating. And, Lisa Miller is the pioneering researcher who created the field. This book is the distillation of her decades of work to help us apply her research to our (Heroic!) ‚ÄúQuests for an Inspired Life.‚Äù Lisa is also the founder and director of the Spirituality Mind Body Institute, the first Ivy League graduate program in spirituality and psychology. And, she is the New York Times bestselling author of The Spiritual Child and a professor in the clinical psychology program at Teachers College, Columbia University. As you‚Äôd expect, the book is packed with Big Ideas. I‚Äôm excited to share some of my favorites so let‚Äôs jump straight in!

title: Happy Together
subtitle: Using the Science of Positive Psychology to Build Love That Lasts
author: Suzann Pileggi Pawelski, MAPP, James O. Pawelski Ph.D.
desc: Suzie and James Pawelski are two of the world's leading positive psychology experts. James cofounded the Master of Applied Positive Psychology program at the University of Pennsylvania with Martin Seligman while Suzie is a graduate of the program and a leading freelance writer and consultant. Together they've written an incredible book on "Using the Science of Positive Psychology to Build Love That Lasts." I‚Äôve been waiting for a very long time for the book that would make me say: ‚ÄúREAD THIS BOOK if you want to figure out how to integrate Ancient Wisdom + Modern Science + Practical Tools to Optimize your relationship.‚Äù And, well, THIS book is it. I HIGHLY recommend it. In fact, it's not only my #1 Love book recommendation, it's also cracked the Top 10 all-time greatest list. Big Ideas we explore include The Relationship Gym (hit it!), Aristotelian Lovers (the REAL Soul Mates), SNAP (James geniuses x2), Know Thy... (self and thy partner!), and Love Is an Action Verb (let's commit to flourishing together TODAY!).

title: The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work
subtitle: A Practical Guide from the Country's Foremost Relationship Expert
author: John M. Gottman, Nan Silver
desc: Want to make your relationship work? Then you‚Äôd be wise to turn toward the world‚Äôs leading researcher on the science of what makes love work: John Gottman. This book has sold over 1 million copies and it‚Äôs easy to see why. Big Ideas we explore: How Gottman can predict divorce with 91% accuracy (in < 15 minutes), a quick look at the 7 principles, the power of cherishing your partner, turning toward (and not being a tech rat), how to solve the solvable problems and starting ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù with the ‚ÄúI.‚Äù

title: The How of Happiness
subtitle: A Scientific Approach to Getting the Life You Want
author: Sonja Lyubomirsky
desc: People often ask me what *one* book I would recommend they read. I never had an answer I felt good about until I read this book. It's amazing. The most comprehensive and readable look at what we *scientifically know* works to boost our happiness‚Äîfrom gratitude and exercise to optimism and kindness. (btw: The other #1 book I'd recommend? The PhilosophersNotes workbook. How can you beat 1,000 Big Ideas from 100 great books packed into 600 pages? ;)

title: The Upside of Stress
subtitle: Why Stress Is Good for You, and How to Get Good at It
author: Kelly McGonigal
desc: If you‚Äôve ever had stress in your life (hah!) and wondered how to deal with it more optimally, I think you‚Äôll love this. McGonigal tells us that how we THINK about stress plays a huge role in its affect on us and walks us thru the science behind it. Rather than try to get rid of stress (good luck with that!), we‚Äôre much better off shifting our mindsets to embrace and use the stress wisely!

title: The Happiness Hypothesis
subtitle: Finding Modern Truth in Ancient Wisdom
author: Jonathan Haidt
desc: Wonder where happiness comes from? So does Jonathan Haidt, one of the world‚Äôs leading positive psychologists and Professor at the University of Virginia. In this phenomenal book, Haidt looks at ancient wisdom and modern wisdom as he tests some happiness hypotheses and comes up with his ultimate hypothesis. In this Note, we‚Äôll check out the dynamic between you and your elephant, the magic pill that is meditation, and the mojo of virtue.

title: Flow
subtitle: The Psychology of Optimal Experience
author: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
desc: Flow. It's all about the science of optimal human experience. In this Note, we'll explore what the flow state is (hint: get fully engaged in an activity that matches your skills with your challenge) and we‚Äôll look at some other Big Ideas on controlling the contents of our consciousness to get out of anxiety and boredom as we create more flow experiences in our lives. (Plus, you'll even learn how to pronounce "Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi.")

title: The Myths of Happiness
subtitle: What Should Make You Happy, but Doesn't, What Shouldn't Make You Happy, but Does
author: Sonja Lyubomirsky
desc: Sonja Lyubomirsky is one of the world‚Äôs leading positive psychology researchers. Her award-winning and very well-funded research is on ‚Äúthe possibility of permanently increasing happiness.‚Äù <‚Äî How cool is that? This book focuses on, you guessed it, the myths of happiness‚Äîthose things we *think* will make us happy (or devastated) but don‚Äôt. The book has over 700 (!) scholarly references. I always love connecting ancient wisdom and fun self-help with SOLID research so this book was a great treat. Big Ideas: hedonic adaptation, #1 way to boost optimism (kinda surprising), the ultradian dip, affluenza virus, frequency > intensity and how to set goals.

title: The Psychology of Hope
subtitle: You Can Get There from Here
author: Charles R. Snyder
desc: Rick Snyder was the founder of research into the science of hope. And, he was one of the pioneers of the positive psychology movement. In fact, he literally wrote the textbook on ‚ÄúPositive Psychology.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include the three components of hope (goals + willpower + way power), the portrait of a high-hope person, how to create the right goals, remembering you WILL face obstacles, the power of multiple pathways and being a time traveler making a difference.

title: Making Hope Happen
subtitle: Create the Future You Want for Yourself and Others
author: Shane J. Lopez, PhD
desc: Did you know there's a science of hope? Yep. And Shane Lopez is the world's leading researchig studying the science of hope. This book is an inspiring look at the nuts and bolts of cultivating hope. Big Ideas we explore include differentiating hope from fantastizing and dwelling, the three keys to hope (goals + agency + pathways) , futurecasting, sirens, when/where plans and why hope is so important for leadership.

title: Constructive Living
subtitle: Outgrow Shyness, Depression, Fear, Stress, Grief, Chronic Pain. Achieve the Goal of Constructive Living - To Do Everything Well
author: David K. Reynolds
desc: Dan Millman (author of Way of the Peaceful Warrior and other great books) introduced me to this book as he's been deeply influenced by David Reynolds' integration of Zen Buddhism and Western Psychotherapy. In this Note, we'll explore some Big Ideas on how to live with greater self-mastery by more effectively relating to our emotions and consistently asking ourselves: "Now what needs to be done?!"

title: Creativity
subtitle: The Psychology of Discovery and Invention
author: Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
desc: Creativity with a capital C‚Äîthe type of Creativity that changes the world. How can we go about cultivating it in our lives? That‚Äôs what this book is all about. Our guide is the legendary psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. Big Ideas we explore include defining true Creativity, focusing our attention and being willing to be kinda weird, the one personality trait all Creators have in common (hint: complexity!), creating rhythms and the nine elements of flow and how to tap into it!

title: The As If Principle
subtitle: The Radically New Approach to Changing Your Life
author: Richard Wiseman
desc: William James once said: ‚ÄúIf you want a quality, act as if you already have it.‚Äù In this book, Richard Wiseman, Britain‚Äôs official professor in ‚Äúthe Public Understanding of Psychology‚Äù walks us through the astonishing array of research that proves what he calls the ‚ÄúAs If Principle.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include an exploration of the fact that feelings follow behavior, how to make yourself happy, the paradox of rewards, and how to create a new you.

title: Thanks!
subtitle: How Practicing Gratitude Can Make You Happier
author: Robert A. Emmons
desc: Robert Emmons is one of the world's leading experts on the science of gratitude and this book is packed with the whys and hows of getting our gratitude on. In this Note, we'll explore Big Ideas on how we can boost our happiness by 25% by simply keeping a daily gratitude journal, how to get our relationships flourishing, the importance of seeing challenges as opportunities for growth and more goodness.

title: Authentic Happiness
subtitle: Using the New Positive Psychology to Realize Your Potential for Lasting Fulfillment
author: Martin Seligman
desc: Martin Seligman is essentially the father of the Positive Psychology movement and in this Note we explore how important it is for us to use our Signature Strengths consistently throughout our day-to-day lives. We've got tips on how to discover our Strengths and how to move from a job to a career to a calling as we live a life of meaning and purpose. Good times.

title: Learned Optimism
subtitle: How to Change Your Mind and Your Life
author: Martin Seligman
desc: Did you know you can learn optimism? Yep. And, unfortunately, we can also learn helplessness. Whether we're helpless or optimistic is one of the biggest predictors of whether we're emotionally happy/healthy or depressed/unhealthy so this is BIG. In this Note, we'll explore some great Ideas on how to get our optimism on by creating more empowering explanations of what's happening in our lives.

title: The Courage Quotient
subtitle: How Science Can Make You Braver
author: Robert Biswas-Diener
desc: Robert Biswas-Diener is known as the ‚ÄúIndiana Jones of positive psychology.‚Äù As per his bio, ‚Äúhis research has taken him to such far-flung places as Greenland, India, Kenya and Israel.‚Äù And, important note: ‚ÄúHe is afraid of quicksand and snakes.‚Äù :) Robert is also the son of one of the leading positive psychology researchers: Ed Diener. We covered a book they wrote together called Happiness. This is basically the ONLY book on science of courage. It's fantastic. Big Ideas we explore include defining the numerator and denominator of our Courage Quotient (hint: Increase your "willingness to act" and "ability to control fear"), courage's two flavors (general + personal), courage blindness (and how to heal it), the power of playing our roles well (choose a courageous one!), being willing to fail and playing to win.

title: The Philosophy of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy
subtitle: Stoic Philosophy as Rational and Cognitive Psychotherapy
author: Donald Robertson
desc: Got problems with your soul? These days, you‚Äôd see a psychotherapist. But, back in the day, it was the philosopher who‚Äôd help you optimize‚Äîthey were the preferred physician of the soul. This book is about the philosophical roots of modern psychotherapy. Specifically, it outlines the connection between cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and Stoicism. Big Ideas we explore include being a warrior of the mind vs. a librarian of the mind, your highest human purpose, getting on good terms with your inner daimon, practicing the reserve clause and modeling your ideal sage.

title: The Power of Ideals
subtitle: The Real Story of Moral Choice
author: William Damon, Anne Colby
desc: William Damon and Anne Colby are two of the world‚Äôs leading researchers in the field of moral psychology. They‚Äôre both Professors at Stanford and have been married for 30+ years. This is a thoughtful and thought-provoking book that challenges the ‚Äúnew science of morality‚Äù‚Äôs view that morality is essentially biologically and socially determined. Damon and Colby argue that we all have the power to cultivate our more noble, moral possibilities. Big Ideas we explore include a quick look at our moral exemplars, moral agency, and the three virtues we want to cultivate: Truth + Humility + Faith.

title: The Marshmallow Test
subtitle: Why Self-Control Is the Engine of Success
author: Walter Mischel
desc: The Marshmallow Test. It was Walter Mischel and his team who (50 years ago!) first started testing whether kids could wait 20 minutes to get two marshmallows (or other attractive treats) or if they‚Äôd give in and eat the one marshmallow in front of them. Their ability to delay gratification (or not!) led to shocking correlations related to how they fared on all kinds of measures years + decades later‚Äîfrom SAT performance to body mass index. Here‚Äôs the guide on how to develop your self-control.

title: The Power of Character Strengths
subtitle: Appreciate and Ignite Your Positive Personality
author: Robert E. McGrath, Ryan M. Niemiec

This book is ‚ÄúAn Official Guide from the VIA Institute on Character‚Äù that helps us ‚ÄúAppreciate and Ignite Your Positive Personality.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include a quick look at the VIA origin story, the 24 character strengths (you know the Top 5?), finding balance (underuse vs. overuse vs. optimal use!) and the Top 2: Hope + Zest!

title: Character Strengths Matter
subtitle: How to Live a Full Life (Positive Psychology News)
author: Shannon M. Polly, MAPP, ACC, Kathryn Britton, MAPP
desc: This is a great introduction to the science of why character strengths matter along with some practical tools on how to go about using those strengths in service to our families and communities so we can experience a deeper sense of joyful flourishing. In this book, Shannon Polly and Kathryn Britton walk us through each of the 24 character strengths identified by the VIA Institute on Character that was created by Martin Seligman and Christopher Peterson. In our Note, we take a quick look at all 24 virtues and explore some practical ways to apply them to our lives TODAY.

title: The Pursuit of Perfect
subtitle: How to Stop Chasing Perfection and Start Living a Richer, Happier Life
author: Tal Ben-Shahar

And Tal Ben-Shahar, the former Harvard (Positive Psych) Professor shares why we should care, and how we can look to our ideals as guiding stars rather than distant shores. If you, like me, have perfectionist tendencies, you'll love the book and you'll love the Note as we explore some Big Ideas on how to embrace the constraints of life as we get our inner-optimalist on!

title: The Power of Agency
subtitle: The 7 Principles to Conquer Obstacles, Make Effective Decisions, and Create a Life on Your Own Terms
author: Dr. Paul Napper, Anthony Rao Ph. D.

Paul Napper and Anthony Rao are leading consultants and clinicians (who have both held academic positions at Harvard Medical School). In their great book, they define agency as ‚Äúthe ability to act as an effective agent for yourself‚Äîreflecting, making creative choices, and constructing a meaningful life.‚Äù Then they provide practical, scientifically-grounded wisdom on, as per the sub-title of the book: ‚ÄúThe 7 Principles to Conquer Obstacles, Make Effective Decisions, and Create a Life on Your Own Terms.‚Äù In this Note, we take a quick look at the 7 principles and shine a spotlight on the first 3 with a focus on how we can Optimize our agency TODAY!!

title: Counterclockwise
subtitle: Mindful Health and the Power of Possibility
author: Ellen Langer
desc: Ellen Langer is a professor of psychology at Harvard and one of the world's leading reseachers who has been exploring what she calls the "psychology of possibility" for over three decades. This book is packed with amazing research stories and wisdom to bring more mindfulness to our lives and tap into our latent potential.

title: Happiness
author: Ed Diener, Robert Biswas-Diener
desc: Ed Diener is the world‚Äôs leading researcher on the science of happiness and his son, Robert Biswas-Diener is known as the ‚ÄúIndiana Jones of psychology‚Äù because of his data collection adventures around the world. (Love that. :) In their great book, Happiness, they give us a comprehensive look at what we KNOW creates happiness. In this Note, we‚Äôll have some fun figuring out how we can become psychological billionaires as we master the happiness equation, become loving and caring angels, and take AIM at happiness.

title: Emotional Intelligence
subtitle: The Groundbreaking Book That Redefines What it Means to be Smart
author: Daniel Goleman

In this Note, we'll explore some (really) Big Ideas on how to scientifically get our emotional intelligence on‚Äîfrom the power of delaying gratification to how worrying can act as self-fulfilling prophecies.

title: Why We Do What We Do
subtitle: Understanding Self-Motivation
author: Edward L. Deci
desc: Edward L. Deci is one of the world‚Äôs leading researchers on human motivation and this book is *packed* with scientific wisdom‚Äîexploring what we know about the power of intrinsic motivation (vs. extrinsic motivation), the importance of autonomy (vs. being controlled) and the need for authenticity (vs. alienation). Hint: If you want happiness, focus on relationships, personal growth and making a contribution; don‚Äôt go after fame, wealth and beauty.

title: Self-theories
subtitle: Their Role in Motivation, Personality, and Development (Essays in Social Psychology)
author: Carol Dweck
desc: Carol Dweck is one of the world‚Äôs leading researchers on the science of motivation. This book is a collection of brief essays on various aspects of ‚Äúself-theories.‚Äù It‚Äôs essentially a bridge between her extensive academic research studies and her popular book Mindset. It‚Äôs amazing. Big Ideas we explore include the two frameworks (entity vs. incremental) and their two goals (performance vs. learning), attributional retraining (aka learning the best way to respond to failure!), and moving from contingent self-worth to wholehearted self-esteem.

title: Mindset
subtitle: The New Psychology of Success
author: Carol Dweck
desc: Carol Dweck, Ph.D is a Stanford Professor and one of the world‚Äôs leading authorities on the science of motivation. She tells us that our ‚Äúmindset‚Äù‚Äîhow we see the world‚Äîdetermines a *huge* part of our overall happiness and well-being and achievement. In this Note, we‚Äôll explore the difference between a ‚Äúfixed mindset‚Äù and a ‚Äúgrowth mindset‚Äù and some Big Ideas on why we want to learn how to live from a growth mindset. And, of course, how to do it!

title: Willpower
subtitle: Rediscovering the Greatest Human Strength
author: Roy Baumeister, John Tierney
desc: Willpower. It‚Äôs ESSENTIAL to optimizing our lives. In fact, in their *great* book, Willpower, Roy Baumeister (one of the world‚Äôs leading scientific researchers on self-control) and John Tierney (science writer for the New York Times) tell us that ‚ÄúImproving willpower is the surest way to a better life.‚Äù In this Note, we‚Äôll learn how to eat our way to willpower (seriously), how to exercise our self-control muscles, why ‚Äúprecommitment‚Äù is so important and how to win the willpower game with bright lines and a great offense. :)

title: The Willpower Instinct
subtitle: How Self-Control Works, Why It Matters, and What You Can Do to Get More of It
author: Kelly McGonigal
desc: Willpower. It‚Äôs huge. The Willpower Instinct by award-winning Stanford Professor Kelly McGonigal, Ph.D., is a GREAT book based on ‚ÄúThe Science of Willpower‚Äù class Kelly teaches through Stanford University‚Äôs Continuing Studies program. It‚Äôs *packed* with super practical Big Ideas on the newest scientific insights about self-control to explain how we can ‚Äúbreak old habits and create healthy habits, conquer procrastination, find our focus, and manage stress.‚Äù In this Note, we‚Äôll check out the #1 way to build willpower (it‚Äôs not what you‚Äôd guess), how to give ourselves willpower boosts throughout the day and other stress-relief strategies that rock.

title: The Paradox of Choice - Why More Is Less
author: Barry Schwartz
desc: Barry Schwartz tells us that some choice is obviously good but too much choice can actually stress us out! The book is packed with powerful wisdom‚Äîmuch of it counterintuitive. In the Note, we'll explore the difference between being a ‚ÄúMaximizer‚Äù vs. a ‚ÄúSatisficer‚Äù and why we want to shift from always needing the ‚Äúabsolute best‚Äù to being happy with ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù as we develop our gratitude and quit comparing ourselves to other peeps. Powerful.

title: A Guide to Rational Living
author: Albert Ellis, Robert Harper
desc: Albert Ellis has been recognized as one of the most influential psychologists of the 20th century (#2, in fact, right ahead of Freud and behind Carl Rogers). title: Toward a Psychology of Being
author: Abraham Maslow
desc: Abraham Maslow sits in the great-grandfather slot in my spiritual family tree and is kinda the great-grandfather of the modern Positive Psychology movement. We profiled the 19 characteristics of his self-actualizing individual in our Note on Motivation & Personality in Volume I and in this Note we take a look at the essence of creativity and the fact that we all have capacities that‚Äôre clamoring to be used!

title: The Upward Spiral

author: Alex Korb, PhD
desc: Alex Korb is a neuroscientist in the department of psychiatry at the University of California, Los Angeles. (Go Bruins!) He‚Äôs also a great writer. Practical. ‚Üê A winning formula for a great book! Big Ideas we explore include the power of exercising your brain (which is the #1 tip, btw), setting goals (and making decisions), developing positive habits (via repetition, repetition, repetition), biofeedback (and how to take advantage of it), and the power of others (rely on it!).

title: I Can If I Want To

author: Arnold Lazarus, Allen Fay, M.D.
desc: This is a fantastic, old school psychology classic. title: Getting Grit
subtitle: The Evidence-Based Approach to Cultivating Passion, Perseverance, and Purpose
author: Caroline Adams Miller, MAPP

title: Pursuing the Good Life
subtitle: 100 Reflections on Positive Psychology
author: Christopher Peterson
desc: Christopher Peterson was an award-winning professor at the University of Michigan. He was also one of the founders of the positive psychology movement. This book is essentially a collection of 100 blog posts Chris created for his popular blog on Psychology Today. Big Ideas we explore include: good hope and bad hope, how to truly matter, how to avoid a sub-optimal epitaph and the keys to flourishing relationships.

title: Positive Psychology and the Body

title: Stoicism 101

title: The Enchiridion
author: Epictetus

title: Discourses
author: Epictetus
desc: Epictetus is known as one of the world‚Äôs leading Stoic philosophers. (Along with Seneca and Marcus Aurelius, the three make up a very interesting bunch.) Epictetus was a former slave turned philosopher who lived from 55-135 (a little later than Seneca and before Aurelius). This book is a transcription of the informal lectures Epictetus gave to his students. It‚Äôs awesome. Big Ideas we explore: why Hercules needed challenges (and so do you), what figs can teach us about greatness, the good + the bad + the indifferent and how to tell the difference, ‚Äúimpressions‚Äù and the tricks they play, and the fact NOW is the time to live this stuff.

title: Letters from a Stoic
author: Seneca
desc: Seneca. He was born around the same time as Jesus and was one of the leading figures in his Roman Empire. He was also one of history's leading Stoic philosophers (along with Marcus Aurelius and Epictetus who we also profile) and has some powerful wisdom to share. In this Note, we'll explore the purpose of philosophy, the importance of focusing our attention and the mojo that comes from facing our fears.

Big Ideas we explore include making T.O.D.A.Y. the day, how to deal with being exiled (never know when it could happen ;), and why flexibility is the virtuous road to tranquility (and how to avoid the detours).

title: Musonius Rufus
subtitle: Lectures and Sayings
author: Musonius Rufus
desc: Musonius Rufus was one of the four great Roman Stoics. In fact, he was known as the ‚ÄúRoman Socrates.‚Äù To put him in historical context with the other three great Roman Stoics: He was born in AD 30, about 34 years after Seneca. He taught Epictetus (who was born in AD 55). Epictetus died in 135 but taught the guys who taught the Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius (who was born in AD 121) his Stoic philosophy‚Äîwhich is why Aurelius refers to him more than any other teacher in Meditations. Big Ideas we explore include: Theory vs. Practice (which is more important?), practicing philosophy (is where it's at!), vice vs. exile (free yourself from vice!), food (it's the medicine of life), and stoic love advice (competing in kindness).

Big Ideas we explore include spiritual exercises, your inner citadel, your daim≈çn, amor fate, turning obstacles upside down and carpe aret√©.

title: How to Be Free
subtitle: An Ancient Guide to the Stoic Life (Ancient Wisdom for Modern Readers)
author: Epictetus, A. A. Long
desc: A.A. Long is professor emeritus of classics and affiliated professor of philosophy at the University of California, Berkeley. As per the inside flap, in this beautiful little (hand)book, he provides ‚Äúsplendid new translations and the original Greek on facing pages, a compelling introduction that sets Epictetus in context and describes the importance of Stoic freedom today, and an invaluable glossary of key words and concepts. The result is an unmatched introduction to this powerful method of managing emotions and handling life‚Äôs situations, from the most ordinary to the most demanding.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include freedom vs. slavery, the ultimate target (progress!), wisdom daggers (ready at hand), Rule #1 of Stoicism, how to win at life and using our full powers.

title: How to Be a Stoic
subtitle: Using Ancient Philosophy to Live a Modern Life
author: Massimo Pigliucci

In this book, Professor Pigliucci teaches us how to be a Stoic via an imaginary dialogue with Epictetus, one of the leading Stoic teachers of the ancient world. It‚Äôs a wonderfully written, super-smart look at how we can use ‚Äúancient philosophy to live a modern life.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include an introduction to our guide Epictetus, Rule #1 of Stoicism (some things are in our power, others are not), the cardinal virtues (of Stoicism + Science + Optimize), the power of role models (and the Stoic Paradox), and the ultimate how to be a Stoic practice question: How can I use virtue here and now?

Big Ideas we explore include Principle #1 of practical Stoicism (Judgment!), the good life vs. the good mood (virtue for the win!), what others think (‚Üê pro tip: ignore it), preferred indifference (committed but not attached), and using adversity as fuel for our Optimizing (use Hermes' magic wand!).

title: The Philosophy of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy
subtitle: Stoic Philosophy as Rational and Cognitive Psychotherapy
author: Donald Robertson
desc: Got problems with your soul? These days, you‚Äôd see a psychotherapist. But, back in the day, it was the philosopher who‚Äôd help you optimize‚Äîthey were the preferred physician of the soul. Big Ideas we explore include being a warrior of the mind vs. a librarian of the mind, your highest human purpose, getting on good terms with your inner daimon, practicing the reserve clause and modeling your ideal sage.

title: The Stoic Challenge
subtitle: A Philosopher's Guide to Becoming Tougher, Calmer, and More Resilient
author: William B. Irvine
desc: William B. Irvine is a professor of philosophy at Wright State University. He‚Äôs also a fantastic (and prolific) writer. And‚Ä¶ Unlike many of his academic, professor-of-philosophy peers, he is a practicing Stoic philosopher. In the words of Donald Robertson (another Stoic author and practitioner; see The Philosophy of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy), he is both a librarian AND a warrior of the mind. We featured another one of Professor Irvine‚Äôs great books on Stoicism called A Guide to the Good Life. I enjoyed that one quite a bit but I REALLY (!) enjoyed this one. Like, jumbo loved it. In fact, I‚Äôm going to put this one right at the top of our growing collection of books on Stoicism‚Äîalong with the must-read classics by Aurelius (Meditations), Seneca (Letters from a Stoic, On the Shortness of Life), and Epictetus (Discourses, Enchiridion) plus the modern classics like Ryan Holiday‚Äôs The Obstacle Is the Way and The Daily Stoic. If you‚Äôre looking for ‚ÄúA Philosopher‚Äôs Guide to Becoming Tougher, Calmer, and More Resilient,‚Äù I think you‚Äôll enjoy it as much as I did. I HIGHLY recommend it.

title: Thoughts of a Philosophical Fighter Pilot
author: James Stockdale
desc: Vice Admiral James Stockdale is an American hero. Stockdale spent nearly eight years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam. He was the commanding officer of hundreds of other U.S. soldiers and received the Medal of Honor for his service beyond the call of duty. This is an incredibly inspiring look at the powerful mind and equally powerful moral commitment of a hero. Big Ideas we explore: Being our brother‚Äôs keeper, chiseling our integrity to achieve delight with life, courage as endurance of the soul and heroes vs. bums.

title: Courage Under Fire
subtitle: Testing Epictetus's Doctrines in a Laboratory of Human Behavior

title: Leadership 101

title: The Leadership Challenge

author: James Kouzes, Barry Posner

Big Ideas we explore: The 5 Practices (‚Üê key word!) of Exemplary Leaders, the foundation of leadership (= credibility which = ‚Ä¶), Law #2: DWYSYWD, and the best-kept secret of leadership = ‚Ä¶

title: Lead Yourself First

author: Raymond M. Kethledge, Michael S. Erwin

We are losing solitude without even realizing it.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include the big 4 of solitude (clarity + creativity + emotional balance + moral courage), the threats from our "Input Age," how MLK and Eisenhower used solitude, FOMO (get over it!) and how to change the world (starting with YOU!).

After a super quick look at the 21 Laws, Big Ideas we explore: The Law of Process (aka: Leaders are learners), the foundation of leadership (= trust), leaders are practical AND visionary, the law of victory (!), and your legacy‚Äîwhat will people say when you die? + What‚Äôs your ‚Äúlife sentence‚Äù?

title: The Wisdom of the Bullfrog
subtitle: Leadership Made Simple (But Not Easy)
author: Admiral William H. McRaven
desc: This is our fourth Note on one of Admiral McRaven‚Äôs great books. As we discussed in the previous Notes, as a four-star admiral, McRaven‚Äôs final assignment was as Commander of all U.S. Special Operations Forces. He served as a Navy SEAL for 37 years. By the time he hit 34 years of service, he was officially anointed as the ‚ÄúBull Frog‚Äù‚Äîthe longest serving frogman and Navy SEAL on active duty. This book, as per the title, is wisdom from this legendary bullfrog. McRaven distills leadership into its most fundamental components, delivering on the subtitle: ‚ÄúLeadership Made Simple (But Not Easy).‚Äù As you‚Äôd expect, it‚Äôs PACKED with practical wisdom.

title: Call Sign Chaos
subtitle: Learning to Lead
author: Jim Mattis, Bing West
desc: General Jim Mattis is the former Secretary of Defense and one of the most formidable strategic thinkers of the twenty-first century. This book is, as per the back cover, ‚Äúa clear-eyed account of learning to lead in a chaotic world‚Äù in which Mattis ‚Äúrecounts the foundational experiences and lessons he learned over four decades and in three wars. It is a journey about learning to lead at every level, with insights equally applicable to the military, to business, and to individual growth.‚Äù I got this book on the recommendation of a new, dear friend who happens to be a long-time student (and Heroic Coach) who also happens to be a commanding officer in the U.S. military. It‚Äôs an absolutely FANTASTIC memoir packed with wisdom on how to lead‚Äîwhich is why it has nearly 5,000 5-star reviews. The book reminds me of two other memoirs by military leaders I admire: Admiral William McRaven‚Äôs Sea Stories and General Colin Powell‚Äôs It Worked for Me. It also reminds me of Phil Knight‚Äôs memoir Shoe Dog and Ray Dalio‚Äôs Principles. And... For related books on leadership, check out our Notes on General Stanley McChrystal‚Äôs Leaders: Myths and Reality plus Doris Kearns Goodwin‚Äôs Leadership in Turbulent Times. As you‚Äôd expect, this book is packed with Big Ideas. I‚Äôm excited to share some of my favorites so let‚Äôs jump straight in!

title: On Becoming a Leader
author: Warren Bennis
desc: Warren Bennis is one of the world‚Äôs leading authorities on leadership. This is, as Peter Drucker puts it, his ‚Äúmost important book.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include the basic ingredients of leadership (#1 = Guiding Vision!), the importance of self-invention (hint: write your own story!), the power of trusting ourselves, choosing to express ourselves rather than prove ourselves, how to cultivate trust, and becoming a world-class leader.

title: Leaders

author: General (Ret.) Stanley McChrystal, Jeff Eggers, Jason Mangone
desc: I got this book after I saw General Stanley McChrystal‚Äôs blurb on the back of Ryan Holiday‚Äôs Lives of the Stoics. I read it in one 8.8-hour Deep Work-filled day. It‚Äôs fantastic. McChrystal uses Plutarch and his profiles of some of history‚Äôs most prominent figures as his inspiration and focuses on thirteen leaders in six pairs plus one standing alone. Almost all leadership books are prescriptive in nature. This book is not. Rather than make us believe that there‚Äôs a nice, simple recipe for leadership, McChrystal, Eggers and Mangone present us with the ‚Äúmyths‚Äù of leadership and the MUCH MESSIER ‚Äúrealities‚Äù of leadership. After the profiles of the thirteen leaders, the authors present the three myths of leadership and their new definition of leadership. We end the book with the sober recognition of just how complex, dynamic and context-specific good leadership is. It‚Äôs a challenging, important book that‚Äôs difficult to distill into a nice and tidy and practical 6-page Note but I‚Äôm excited to share some of my favorite Ideas as we all continue to step up into our own idiosyncratic expressions of Heroic leadership. So... Let‚Äôs get to work!

title: The Effective Executive

author: Joe De Sena

The. Work (eat frogs and dominate), Pressure (pressure, pressure! subtitle: The Sub-Two-Hour Marathon Is Within Reach‚ÄïHere's How It Will Go Down, and What It Can Teach All Runners about Training and Racing

Enter, this class‚Äîwhich could more accurately be called Optimal METABOLISM 101. Fact is, if our weight is off, our METABOLISM is off. Specifically, our insulin levels (which disrupts another hormone called leptin that regulates our appetite). In this class, we take a quick look at why it‚Äôs so hard to Optimize our weight and how to make it easy (or at least a lot easier!).

title: Optimal Nutrition 101
desc: Nutrition. It‚Äôs easy to get lost in the labyrinth of conflicting science. In this class, we focus on the 2 facts Michael Pollan tells us we can all agree on and then look at how to eliminate the primary causes of disease caused by our modern diets. Optimizing our health, energy and happiness starts at the end of our fork!

title: Food Rules
subtitle: An Eater's Manual
author: Michael Pollan
desc: Energy, Nutrition, Modern Classic Michael Pollan is the author of a number of New York Times best-selling books on nutrition. In 2010, Time magazine named him one of the one hundred most influential people in the world. If you‚Äôre looking for a SUPER compact, witty look at the primary rules on how to eat well, this is it. It‚Äôs a fun, witty, concise guide to eating well featuring 64 food rules structured around Pollan‚Äôs seven words of wisdom: Eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants. Big Ideas we explore include the 2 Facts of nutrition everyone can agree on, Rule #1, why low-fat made us fat, and the final rule (#64).

title: In Defense of Food
subtitle: An Eater's Manifesto
author: Michael Pollan
desc: Michael Pollan is one of the world‚Äôs leading thinkers on nutrition. Time magazine voted him one of the 100 most influential people in the world. He‚Äôs also a Professor of Journalism at UC Berkeley. One of the things I most love about him and his work is that, as a journalist, he takes a much wider, more objective view of the nutritional landscape‚Äîwhich can often be dominated by (and muddled by) individuals with *very* strong, dogmatic, inflexible ideologies. Big Ideas we explore: Nutritionism (vs. food), the big experiment (that failed), the Aborigine in all of us, the 5 fundamental transformations of industrializing food and Lucky Charms, Cocoa Puff and Trix cereals as health foods as per the American Heart Association. (<‚Äî Can you believe that? Crazy. And true.)

title: Bright Line Eating
subtitle: The Science of Living Happy, Thin & Free
author: Susan Peirce Thompson
desc: Susan Peirce Thompson is a Professor of Brain and Cognitive Sciences at the University of Rochester. She‚Äôs an expert in the psychology of eating and creator of Bright Line Eating Solutions, ‚Äúa company dedicated to helping people achieve long-term, sustainable weight loss.‚Äù Plus... She used to be obese and, as she says, addicted to *everything.* She integrates her background in neuroscience with her personal experience conquering her diet and other addiction issues in this super popular book. Big Ideas we explore include why bright lines are where it‚Äôs at, the susceptibility quiz, the saboteur, self-perception theory, and the four bright lines of eating.

title: Power Up Your Brain
author: David Perlmutter, MD, Alberto Villoldo, Ph.D.
desc: Q: What do you get when you combine a neuroscientist and a shaman? A: This book! Specifically, as the sub-title suggests we get: ‚ÄúThe Neuroscience of Enlightenment." This is a great book. In the Note, we take a quick look at the power of mitochondria, how to move from our amygala to our prefrontal cortex, how to use stress to our advantage, and create new nueral superhighways.

title: The Case for Keto
subtitle: Rethinking Weight Control and the Science and Practice of Low-Carb/High-Fat Eating
author: Gary Taubes
desc: We‚Äôve featured two of Gary Taubes‚Äô other great books: Why We Get Fat and The Case Against Sugar. If you or a loved one have struggled with reaching your optimal weight while trying to follow the conventional wisdom that all you have to do is eat less and exercise more, I think you, too, will enjoy Taubes‚Äôs thoughtful perspective on just how flawed our current thinking is regarding the cause of obesity. Hint: It‚Äôs not an ‚Äúenergy balance‚Äù issue; it‚Äôs primarily a HORMONAL issue. The book is PACKED with Big Ideas. As in, jumbo packed. Hope you love the Note!

author: Dave Asprey
desc: Want to get Bulletproof? Then Dave Asprey is your man. An uber-successful entrepreneur who weighed 300 lbs before bio-hacking his way to optimal awesome, Dave gives us a guide to upgrading our lives. Big Ideas include the 10 Diet Myths, inflamma, fruits and vegetables, and making health a means to a much bigger end.

author: Brendan Brazier
desc: Brendan Brazier is a former professional Ironman triathlete who lived on nothing but plant-based foods‚Äîno meat, no dairy‚Ä¶ just plants. In the Note, we'll explore some Big Ideas on how to optimize our diets and experience more vitality in our lives as we quit leaking energy, go for high net-gain foods and rock the alkalinity!

title: Eat to Live
subtitle: The Revolutionary Formula for Fast and Sustained Weight Loss
author: Joel Fuhrman
desc: This book is REALLY REALLY good. In fact, I‚Äôm gonna say that if you take the time to read only *one* book on nutrition, read this one. Integrating scientific research plus his experience treating over 10,000 patients with common sense and fun, Dr. Joel Fuhrman has created a super-readable book with a challenging, yet approachable nutrition program that can completely change your life. Big Ideas we explore in the Note include the importance of really committing, what nutritional density is all about and other goodness.

title: Fat for Fuel
subtitle: A Revolutionary Diet to Combat Cancer, Boost Brain Power, and Increase Your Energy
author: Dr. Joseph Mercola
desc: Dr. Mercola is a super-popular alternative health physician who runs the equally popular site Mercola.com. In this book, we get a look at his ‚ÄúMitochondrial Metabolic Therapy‚Äù program. MMT for short. As you could probably guess, this is a high-fat (+ ‚Äúadequate‚Äù protein + low-carb) diet. If that approach fires you up, I think you‚Äôll love the book. If not, well‚Ä¶ :) Big Ideas we explore include: meeting our mitochondria (the key to health), why ‚Äúadequate‚Äù protein is where it‚Äôs at (not low or moderate or high but ‚Äúadequate‚Äù!), mTOR (the cancer switch), good fats (vs. bad ones), peak fasting, and how to win the urge war.

title: The Case Against Sugar
author: Gary Taubes
desc: Gary Taubes is an award-winning science journalist. He‚Äôs a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Investigator in Health Policy Research at the University of California, Berkeley School of Public Health. In this book, we take up the case against sugar as the primary suspect for ALL of the chronic diseases that are killing us. As the back cover says, Taubes ‚Äúmakes the convincing case that sugar is the tobacco of the new millennium: backed by powerful lobbies, entrenched in our lives, and making us very sick.‚Äù Big Ideas we explore include: the prime suspect (= sugar), drug or food?, two theories (energy balance vs. metabolic theory), sugar as a chronic toxin (vs. acute), sugar as candy for cancer cells, and the big question: how little is too much?

title: Natural Born Heroes
subtitle: Mastering the Lost Secrets of Strength and Endurance
author: Christopher McDougall
desc: Christopher McDougall is a brilliant story teller (and author of Born to Run). In the process, he shares a ton of Ideas on how we can each tap into the extraordinary superpowers latent within. Big Ideas we explore include the ancient Greek meaning of the word ‚Äúhero,‚Äù the mantra of the hero, why weeds + fat are optimal fuel and a great test.

Powerful.

(how to wash your brain!).

author: Dan Millman

title: The Spartan Way

title: Natural Born Heroes

author: Christopher McDougall

subtitle: The Sub-Two-Hour Marathon Is Within Reach‚ÄïHere's How It Will Go Down, and What It Can Teach All Runners about Training and Racing
author: Dr. Philip Maffetone

As he says in the sub-title, it‚Äôs all about ‚Äúhow it will go down‚Äù AND ‚Äúwhat it can teach all runners about training and racing.‚Äù If you‚Äôre a marathoner, this might be the perfect way to get introduced to Maffetone‚Äôs core ideas. It‚Äôs basically a holistic look at all the marginal gains we can apply to reach our running potential. Big Ideas we cover include a quick look at just how fast a 1:59 pace is (sub-4:35 min mile for 26.2 miles = CRAZY fast!), the importance of the MIND in hitting the target, why AEROBIC speed is so important (plus, what it is and how to train it), the ideal training schedule (is super dynamic and personal), how to run properly (hot coal technique!), and balancing the catabolic + anabolic phases of training.

title: The Endurance Handbook

author: Dr. Philip Maffetone

As I was shining a flash light into all the nooks and crannies of Maffetone‚Äôs brain that I could find (hah), I kinda thought of these two books as a sort of parallel to Epictetus‚Äôs "Discourses" (the ‚ÄúBig Book‚Äù!) and "Enchiridion" (the ‚ÄúHandbook‚Äù!). Big Ideas we explore include Rule #1 (first, do no harm!), Rule #2 (build your aerobic base!), the importance of fat burning (and how to build it), the #1 pro tip (ELIMINATE SUGAR!!!), body economy 101 (uncapping your athletic potential), and winning the ultimate endurance race: life (see you at 100!).

author: Dr. Philip Maffetone

title: The Big Book of Endurance Training and Racing

title: Call Sign Chaos

author: Jim Mattis, Bing West

It also reminds me of Phil Knight‚Äôs memoir Shoe Dog and Ray Dalio‚Äôs Principles. And... For related books on leadership, check out our Notes on General Stanley McChrystal‚Äôs Leaders: Myths and Reality plus Doris Kearns Goodwin‚Äôs Leadership in Turbulent Times. As you‚Äôd expect, this book is packed with Big Ideas. I‚Äôm excited to share some of my favorites so let‚Äôs jump straight in!

title: Learn How to Lead to Win

author: Mike Manazir
desc: Mike Manazir (‚ÄúMuh-naw-zur‚Äù) is a Retired US Navy Admiral and Top Gun Fighter Pilot. My friend recommended Jim Mattis‚Äôs book on leadership (Call Sign Chaos) and that book was so good that I asked him what *other* books on leadership he‚Äôd recommend. He immediately told me about this one. I immediately got it. Manazir was one of his cherished mentors. After reading this great book, I can see why. The book is, as you‚Äôd expect from the title, all about helping us learn how to lead to win. It‚Äôs part memoir, part leadership manual‚Äîfeaturing 33 powerful stories from Admiral Manazir‚Äôs life and the lessons he gained along the way. In fact, as I type that, I realize that this book is kinda like a hybrid of McRaven‚Äôs memoir AND his latest book called The Hero Code. Mash those two books up and swap out the SEAL stories for a Top Gun Fighter Pilot‚Äôs and voil√†‚Äîyou get this book. As you‚Äôd expect, the book is PACKED with Big Ideas. I‚Äôm excited to share some of my favorites so let‚Äôs jump straight in!

title: Leaders
subtitle: Myth and Reality
author: General (Ret.) Stanley McChrystal, Jeff Eggers, Jason Mangone
desc: I got this book after I saw General Stanley McChrystal‚Äôs blurb on the back of Ryan Holiday‚Äôs Lives of the Stoics. I read it in one 8.8-hour Deep Work-filled day. It‚Äôs fantastic. McChrystal uses Plutarch and his profiles of some of history‚Äôs most prominent figures as his inspiration and focuses on thirteen leaders in six pairs plus one standing alone. Almost all leadership books are prescriptive in nature. This book is not. Rather than make us believe that there‚Äôs a nice, simple recipe for leadership, McChrystal, Eggers and Mangone present us with the ‚Äúmyths‚Äù of leadership and the MUCH MESSIER ‚Äúrealities‚Äù of leadership. After the profiles of the thirteen leaders, the authors present the three myths of leadership and their new definition of leadership. We end the book with the sober recognition of just how complex, dynamic and context-specific good leadership is. It‚Äôs a challenging, important book that‚Äôs difficult to distill into a nice and tidy and practical 6-page Note but I‚Äôm excited to share some of my favorite Ideas as we all continue to step up into our own idiosyncratic expressions of Heroic leadership. As per the sub-title, John walks us through the ‚Äú11 Essential Changes‚Äù he has made and that he encourages every leader to embrace. Big Ideas we explore: The 5 Practices (‚Üê key word!) of Exemplary Leaders, the foundation of leadership (= credibility which = ‚Ä¶), Law #2: DWYSYWD, and the best-kept secret of leadership = ‚Ä¶

author: John C. Maxwell

If you‚Äôre looking for ‚ÄúA Philosopher‚Äôs Guide to Becoming Tougher, Calmer, and More Resilient,‚Äù I think you‚Äôll enjoy it as much as I did. I HIGHLY recommend it.

(rather than "I feel anxious."), the fact that a wandering mind is an UNHAPPY mind (crazy studio show it), Hall of Fame researching stats (note: failing nearly 70% of the time), and the power of BELIEVING we can use stress to get stronger (it ALL starts with belief).

title: Optimal Business 101

desc: My brother was recently diagnosed with cancer. As I wrapped my brain around how to best help him, I realized that, unfortunately (and obviously), our family is not alone in fighting cancer. desc: In Conquering Cancer 101 we focused on the nuts-and-bolts of how to Optimize our terrain and make sure we‚Äôre cutting off cancer‚Äôs supply lines while getting our minds strong and aiming for the long tail, etc. Our primary source of inspiration for that class was Anticancer by David Servan-Schreiber and the dozens of references to cancer in other Notes over the years. In Conquering Cancer 102, we cover all the wisdom I‚Äôve picked up since that class over the last month. Theme: Rethinking Cancer: Theory + Therapy. Featuring Big Ideas from Tripping over the Truth (great intellectual overview of the history of cancer theory/therapy), The Metabolic Approach to Cancer (GREAT (!) practical roadmap on how to Optimize terrain by my brother‚Äôs new consulting oncologist), Cancer as a Metabolic Disease (by the leading research scientist on the approach we‚Äôre following), Keto for Cancer (by my brother‚Äôs day-to-day nutritional consultant), and Radical Remission (by a leading researcher on who‚Äôs studied 1,000+ case studies of people who have thrived outside of traditional approaches).

It‚Äôs astonishingly good. I echo Ben‚Äôs advice and say, THIS is the book to read if you or a loved one are dealing with cancer. Dr. Nasha Winters was diagnosed with stage IV terminal ovarian cancer 25 years ago. She was given 3 to 6 months to live and was told Western medicine couldn‚Äôt do anything for her so she committed herself to figuring it out‚Äîbecoming a naturopathic doctor and acupuncturist and fellow of the American Board of Naturopathic Oncology in the process. 25 years later (!) she‚Äôs thriving and has helped thousands of others thrive through cancer by focusing on, as per the title, a ‚Äúmetabolic approach to cancer‚Äù that integrates ‚Äúdeep nutrition, the ketogenic diet, and nontoxic bio-individualized therapies.‚Äù

But, as he drilled into the scientific literature, he realized just how important Optimizing the ‚Äúterrain‚Äù within our bodies is to the prevention and treatment of cancer. This book is an overview of what he discovered. It‚Äôs incredibly thoughtful and thorough. Big Ideas we explore include Genes vs. Habits, cutting off cancer‚Äôs supply lines, the three keys to nutritional detox, the anticancer mind and the best protection against cancer.

He is the leading scientist pointing to (and nearly screaming at!) the SUPER-compelling evidence that says cancer is caused by dysfunctional energy metabolism‚Äîproviding evidence that the genetic mutations are a secondary, downstream epiphenomenon of that primary cause. Big Ideas we explore include the metabolic theory vs. the genetic theory of cancer, nuclear-cytoplasm studies (perhaps the most powerful case for the metabolic theory), metastasis (Mr. Mo builds your MOAT!!), apoptotic vs. necrotic cell death (aka naturel/nontoxic vs. unnatural/toxic), and the cancer solar system (make sure the metabolic cancer-sun is in the discussion!).

Thomas Seyfried is the leading research scientist making the case for the metabolic approach to cancer (vs. as we‚Äôve discussed, a genetic approach). He and Laura Shelton brilliantly and lucidly unpack the case for cancer as a metabolic disease. Bonus: Your brain gets a nice workout as every word is chosen wisely for peer-reviewable hardiness. Big Ideas we explore include the fact that we‚Äôve spent $100 billion researching cancer and spend $100 billion annually on cancer medications and we‚Äôve seen ZERO improvements in the real death rates from cancer since the 1950s. We look at the one prime cause of cancer (via the Warburg Effect), a fascinating experiment with ‚Äúrecon‚Äù cells demonstrating that it's the cytoplasm (not the nucleus) that drives cancer, how to starve cancer and a vision of cancer clinics in the future.
